description.text: A black ABS plastic die made on a makerbot.

On Autodesk Inventor I created a 2x2 inch square. Then I extruded the square 2 inches. This formed a cube. I then made 1/2 inch cirles on each face. The number of circles corresponded to the number value of the side. The circles were then embosed 1/10 of an inch into the cube. Then I made 1/4 inch concentric circles inside of the 1/2 inch circles. These would be embosed 1/20 of an inch. These would be used to put glue on the inside to hold the acrylic dots. The acrylic used was 3mm green acrylic. 0.48 inch circles were made in inventor and cut into the green acrylic on a CNC laser cutter. Then acrylic glue was used to attach the acrylic to the cube.

description.text: A 3D scan of a real icicle. This icicle was grown in a laboratory as part of a study of icicle morphology. All the data from this study is available online in an open source online database called The Icicle Atlas. The ripples, which are commonly found on natural icicles, are the result of a small concentration of salt added to the water. This icicle is the final, fully grown state of Icicle Atlas Run 120206. The 3D file was generated from image 513 and the following 7 successive images. See The Icicle Atlas Run 120206 Image 120206.513 Download more STL files of this icicle at earlier stages of its growth

title: Large belt clip with gluing surface

description.text:
A larger, deeper belt clip for gluing (Goop or ShoeGoo works well) for attaching to DIY phone cases, etc.  
Update: added another version with more and slightly deeper holes on the back for more grip.

("Sources" field is not working for me: new CAD, but inspired by http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:35940). I needed a deeper/larger clip and one with more aggressive hold. Print with high infill for strength since this will get flexed and abused. This design is made for a typical thin dress belt; may require scaling for heavier belts. The 6 divots on the back face are for gluing to shallow rivets or similar structures penetrating through back wall of the case. Update: new version has more holes for more grip, when not using rivets, etc. Will post vid and possibly other sizes/styles ASAP.

title: Gilgamesh Pattern Battle Tank (18mm scale)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Featuring twin-linked, turret mounted heavy energy cannons, this consumer-grade military vehicle is a common sight in mercenary forces and militias throughout the Freespace colonial belt. This tank was modeled for our sci-fantasy tabletop RPG, Wayfarer: Things Beyond Wonder and for Wayfarer Tactics (coming soon). We've set up a Patreon page for anyone who's interested to help fund us so we can keep making free and open sourced games like Pocket-Tactics, Wayfarer Tactics. and others, not to mention the growing catalog of gaming miniatures that you can use for whatever you want! (Psst... we take requests and commissions...) Also, you can find and hack the model on TinkerCAD. Post pics if you make a variant or design some accessories! Enjoy!

Post-Print Assembly: You'll need to glue the body to the treads and the turret ring to the hull. The hull can be removed to show the inside and the turret can swivel and be swapped out with different weapons (soon).

title: Quadrocopter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
• Redesigned for 10 mm round wooden arms as this size was very easily available.
  • Battery is held in place with wide zip-ties.
  • Arms extend to center of the design.
  • Uses Hobby King motors.
    • Here is my whole Hobby King order-list - just in case someone likes to have similar setup. With these components it seems to fly fairly well. Propellers should be 2 x push and 2 x pull but when I ordered these HK didn't have push propellers in stock. 4x #TR_P18A/4312 TURNIGY Plush 18amp Speed Controller = $47.60
    1x #TR_PC/2169 TURNIGY BESC Programming Card = $6.95
    1x #OR019-00501-3/8240 Prop Saver w/ Band 3mm (10pcs) = $2.86
    1x #T2200.3S.20/8932 Turnigy 2200mAh 3S 20C Lipo Pack = $8.49
    4x #AX-2213N/8622 2213N 800Kv Brushless motor for AXN Floater-Jet = $29.44
    3x #HK401B/10113 Hobby King 401B AVCS Digital Head Lock Gyro = $35.97
    1x #GWS-RD-1047/10055 GWS EP Propeller (RD-1047 254x119mm) (6pcs/set) = $4.82
    1x #RBand-21M/11761 Spare Rubber Ring for Prop Saver (10pcs) = $0.99 (optional: "Open Source upgradable frequency hopping transmitter":
    1x #TX-9X-M1/8991 Turnigy 9X 9Ch Transmitter w/ Module & 8ch Receiver (Mode 1) (v2 Firmware) = $53.79) You need also KKmulticopter controller-board or something similar to keep the thing balanced.

Print, assemble, tune and hope for the best :)
Good luck on flying !

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/iYTvEIrfyL6

This is a simple, skateboard bearing-based filament holder for your 3d printer. The two halves press-fit together and the bearings press-fit onto their pegs as shown in the photographs. This is made to be a permanent solution, so the two sides fit together quite snugly, and joining then will require significant force. A few light hammer taps may not be entirely out of place :) While not entirely necessary, 2 screws (#4-40, 3/8") provide extra long-lasting security. *You'll need to print 2 of these for a functional set Bearings: http://amzn.com/B002BBGTK6

title: RostockMax V2 Connector plate
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: So I originally made a simple connector plate for power and USB so the cables didn't come loose out the back of the RostockMax. It's just a power jack and USB panel mount adapter. I saw the vent design by jimustanguitar and I really liked it so I added a version with his vent design in it. You will also notice a power supply back plate in the drawing, while not necessary to use if you haven't put your printer together yet this will make it a lot easier to get the power plug from the PS to the panel. If you don't use it then just drill a hole big enough to pass the power cable through.

A friend of mine has a 2005 Lexus ES 300 and the casings for two of his keys have cracked.
This design is a rugged replacement for the original covers and can be easily opened up when the battery needs replacing. Designed in Moi (Moment of Inspiration) and make in PLA on an Ultimaker 1.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker Original

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

100%

Notes: Check the orientation before printing.
For both pieces the recess should be open and facing upwards so no support is needed for printing. I'm surprised that "Print Settings" doesn't include the material used. I used PLA as I think it more appropriate than ABS (the only other material that I process.)

This is what I did:
  • Cleaned excess material from the button cut-outs with a hobby knife.
  • Cleaned excess material from the 5 small holes with a tapered hand reamer.
  • Cleaned excess material from the round and hexagon counter bores and with a 4mm and 6mm hand reamer.
  • As best I could cleaned excess material from the L and U and B cut-outs.
  • Put the two parts together in the correct orientation and dragged the 3mm hex nuts into the neatly fitting hex holes using a 15mm long 3mm button head cap screw.
  • Made sure that the key 'innards' fitted into the recess and that the buttons operated correctly (turned the LED on and off).
  • Assembled the 2 halves together using 10mm long 3mm button head cap screws (3-off).
  • Fully tightened the screws and then turned the body so the the rectangular opening for the key stem was uppermost, rested the body on a plastic cutting board, and tapped the stem home using a soft hammer.
  • Fastened the 2mm cap head through the stem (this screw was salvaged from the original key).

I disassembled the old key and scanned the top and bottom housings in a flat bed scanner and saved the files as jpgs.
I imported the jpgs into Moment of Inspiration (Moi) and used the images to draw the outline of the recess for the key 'innards' and to draw the size and position of the button and LED cut outs.
Then just designed the rest of the covers.

Here's a quick toolholder for a set of lathe tools. Each piece is positioned to show the normal usage of the tool. Obviously it's no substitute for being trained properly, but it's a nice memory aid for when you come back after a few months and go "What the hell does this one do again?". Cut from 2 layers of plywood and glue together.

The design was extensively edited in SketchUp and cleaned up with NetFabb. Booleans were created in TinkerCAD, Uses a dual-hinge design loosely based on http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:797328. After printing, glue the clip into place.
If your printer has trouble producing working hinges, increasing the Z-height of the model by 5 percent may help.

title: BLTouch Auto Leveling Sensor Mounting Flange

description.text:
This is the flange for the BLTouch Auto Leveling Sensor (see link below) that can be used to mounting the sensor. The OpenSCAD file is included so this can be used to design your own mounting system. The STL files aren't very useful but are included to show the design variants. The OpenSCAD is the useful piece of work for this thing. There are a couple variations. The first is the exact shape of the BLTouch mounting flange. There is minimal surface area to mount this flange, so the second variation is a "rectangular" flange. There is an optional "bracket" that can be added to either flange type. The flange variation, bracket placement, bracket size, etc are all set by parameters. There are no holes in the mounting brackets because I didn't know how others will use this. They will need to be added as necessary, The flange is created as a module and I believe the code is fairly easy to understand. Comment if you have questions. Indiegogo campaign:
https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/bltouch-auto-leveling-sensor-for-3d-printers#/story

Printer:

Cobblebot Basic

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

No

0.25

30%

author: gooy221

description.text: New design for Trintcore...

I bought a Logitech C270 webcam to monitor my printer but it is designed to mount to a monitor/laptop and not a 3D printer so I took it apart, took the board out and made my own mount for it.
I made a bunch of different versions and different length links I only used one style but I figured I might as well make it useful for others. Instructions:
Take apart the camera, mount the circuit board to the new body with the two screws that held it down in the last mount, glue on the back.
For the screws holding the links I used #60-32 screws I picked up from the hardware store, I recommend getting nylon insert lock nuts, I didn't and every time I adjust it the screws loosen, definitely on the agenda for the next hardware store trip.
You don't need the links, they are used to extend or add manuverabilty, technically you just need a mount and the body/back. I may redesign the back to take screws, I couldn't remember how much room there was in the corners but I just took it out of the v1 mount I made a long time ago and there is room for it, add it to the "One day" list. I made it out of black PLA, 0.4mm nozzle, 0.2mm layer height.

comments.text: I know you designed this a few years back, but I was wondering if you still had the .step files you could upload or change the hole size for me on Camera_Mount_Body_Bottom.stl to 5mm from 4mm. I need this to attach to a GoPro Mount. I did try altering the .STL but could not get the hole sizing correct, trying to manually enlarge the hole after print caused it to break. Thank You

author: w4wlc

description.header: My model is about to print. Please wait until it is done printing to see the pictures.
description.text:
Remember those days when teachers had to relentlessly pursue a tiny sample for their classes to understand compounds and elements?
Well, teachers, fear not, as I present...

description.header: H2O: The Intertwinement of Science and 3D Printing
description.text:
This model of a basic compound was made out of just a few basic components and some subtractive designing (aka "Holes" for those of you who don't spend half their life on Make: Magazine). Print this as an example for your students. Read on for design tips, a lesson plan, and more!
"When you combine Tinkercad and Makerbot 3D printers, you get something truly wonderful."
-Luke Ajem

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

100 microns is enough

Infill:

20%

Notes: The above brand is what this is optimized for, but not my actual printer.
View my other educational project at Abstract 3D Bridge-An Art/Engineering Fusion.
Simple, Easy Process Post-print, all you need to do is display it to the class and challenge them with the lesson plan below!
Quite Simple, Really At its roots, this demo is really just three spheres, connected by tether-like boxes, and combined with letter-shaped holes to create a model.

Objectives -Build simple yet complex designs from a baseline
-Take notes on designs Audiences -Designated Grades: 3-8th grade
-Designated Ages: 7-14
-Designated Design Level: Basic Preparation Students need access to a 3D printer, a computer with Wi-Fi, and a Tinkercad account. It's easy to sign up! Just go to Tinkercad. Also, instructors should be prepared to answer questions, and should know how to slice files and print prior to reading this. Lesson Plan Step 1: Choose an Element or Compound to Model Assign groups of two or three to the students, and then assign compounds and/or elements they must model. Give them a total project time of half a week to a week. Step 2: Research Have students research the molecular structure of their assigned compound and have them draw a 2D model on paper (remind them to keep these "notes"). Step 3: Design For the next couple days, have the groups model their compound. Step 4: Print&Review; Open the slicing program and print all models. When finished, review the accuracy of each model and take all the notes from students. Review the project and/or have students present their prints for half a period. Results -Students should have a model of their compound or element
-Students should have a better knowledge of Tinkercad
-Students should have a .stl file or a printed model

author: aliahsan

title: Print Rite DIY 3D Printer - Adapter MK2 MK3 Heat Bed

description.text:
It's an adapter for the MK serie Heatbeds and the Print Rite 3D Printer.
  • Original bed is 21 x 21 cm
  • MK3 bed is 21.4 x 21.4 cm
    • It involve cutting 1cm from the corners of the original Acryl-bed (pictures will follow). 27/11/2015 I already printer the part, M3 screws comes nicely threw. I'll prepare the orginal bed and set the screws and make some pictures later on to confirm the design. Ok! everything is in place. The part is validated ! Tomorrow I'll get the new PSU 12V - 15A, we'll see how it goes ;) 28/11/2015 Z axis stopper screw is to small, you'll have to use a M5 x 80mm. I designed a part to get a better stability for the screw. Work nice. I also added two nuts to secure the screw. See pictures ;) 01/12/2015 New PSU connected (12V-15A). I reach 100°C after 18min. Ill try to get 13V out of it to reach 110V. I didn't manage to print onthe bare luminium surface, I had to spray som hairspray on it to get a grip. Still got some very light warping with ABS at 100°C Heatbed. The PLA corners are holding the 100°C fine, the heat is not propaging downwards, so worries there. The heat bed spent at least 3 hours at 100°C, and there was no problem with the corner parts. 03/12/2015 So, there is an pot on my the PSU (It's a PSU designed for LED stripes 12V15A) and I set it so that I got 13V on the Hetbed connectors. It means the the PSU delivers 13.4V to the Printer. But it manage everything very well. With this setting I can now reach 110°c easily. It still needs 12 to15 minutes, but the curve look nice, not as it were struggeling at all to come there. ABS is not warping anymore at 110°C, I'm printing diretly on the aluminium with Hairspary and a 5mm brimm. 14/01/2016 I made a new version so we can add a part like this one:
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:874155
    for bed levelling. My problem is the head of the inside screw. I put some more height.
    See the picture ;) 14/01/2017
    I found this part on the printer group:
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1659738
    Seems to be a better option :)
    I'm still using my old one, but if I had to do everything again, I would give it a try.

Printer:

Print Rite 3D Printer

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

50

Notes: At the moment the parts are PLA.
I get the part inspiration from this Blog: http://lbsfilm.at/print-rite-diy-a-3d-printer-from-hobbyking/ Thanks for the idea ! I just rebuild the part, adding 3.5mm holes at the right place.

author: studiii

description.text:
Main features:
  • Front side can be easy removed for maintenance tasks
  • Chamber has thermometer measuring temperature inside the printer
  • Back side has a hole for cable and filament tube
  • Pipe is connected by a brace that can be easily disconnected and it should be disconnected when the extractor is switched off
  • Chamber has many useful tool holders
    • This is only an example how you can extend your Zortrax machine.
    Please be aware that this is work in progress. Background history of the project:
    I was looking for a solution to problem with fumes generated by 3d Printers.
    I was surprised by the indifference of people to fumes generated by their devices.
    So as any regular further of a infant child I decided that I will build my own solution for fumes extraction to protect our health.
    Before I bought a 3D printer I decided that this will be my first project :)
    I hope that example presented in the instruction bellow can save us from fumes that are not fully examined. Printed parts: 2 x Window-pipe adapter - ( symbol:WPA ) Bottom parts for chamber:
    2 x Bottom Right Corner ( symbol: CBR )
    2 x Bottom Left Corner ( symbol: CBL )
    2 x 8 cm Front female connectors ( symbol: FFC8 )
    2 x 8 cm Side female connectors ( symbol: SFC8 )
    4 x 1 cm Front male connectors ( symbol: FMC1 )
    4 x 1 cm Side male connectors ( symbol: SMC1 )
    2 x 1 cm Middle male connectors ( symbol: MMC1 )
    1 x Back side adapter ( symbol: BSA ) Top parts for chamber:
    2 x Top Right Corner ( symbol:CTR )
    2 x Top Left Corner ( symbol:CTL )
    2 x Extractor holder ( symbol: EH )
    1 x Thermometer housing ( symbol: TH ) Printing parameters:
  • Material: Z-ULTRAT (Exception: male connectors should be printed with more flexible Z-ABS)
  • Layer thickness: 0.19 mm
  • Infill: Light (Exception: Extractor holders should have full infill)
  • Support: 10 degrees light
    • Corners description:
  • They can warp so I use side covers and try to keep warm air in the room
  • Use mixture with Z-ABS or Z-Ultrat residues and pure Acetone - it creates glue for the surface
  • Circular holes are designed for support removal with help of a scalpel handle (scalpel that is in default toolbox)
  • Circular holes can be also used for screws
    • Male connectors description:
  • they are so small because sticks are very fragile, so it will be easy to replace them
  • print sticks horizontally ( otherwise they will break ! )
  • print with more flexible Z-ABS material
    • Female connectors description:
  • these parts are printed in various orientations, therefore you can expect some discrepancies between the results and the design
    • Window-pipe adapter description:
  • unfortunately I had to print it horizontally, so I can warp
  • I connected 2 parts with ABS slurry
    • Parts that you need to buy in a hardware store:
  • Flexible pipe 3 m (radius 5 cm)
  • 2 x Metal braces for pipe

title: Replacement parts for bicycle/moped umbrella holder

description.text:
So I have this umbrella holder for my bicycle. No, really. Here it is:
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B005GNTB4M/ref=wms_ohs_product?ie=UTF8&psc=1 It's a great design and a great price, except for two problems. First, tightening it to the handlebar tight enough to hold the weight of an umbrella is tricky; my first try, I made the bracket snap in half. Second, and more damningly, the clip that holds the umbrella handle itself has a weak spot and is very easy to snap; I've broken two already. So I set out to make replacements. The bracket replacement wasn't too hard. I made it more solid than the original to help make up for the fact that 3D-printed ABS is not as strong as injection molding. I haven't put it through the ringer yet, but it feels as solid as the original or more so. And you can always print more. But the bracket clip is much trickier. It has all kinds of angles that are tricky to print without supports without them ending up not as smooth or solid as I would like (and printing with supports makes weakness of a different sort when you cut and file them off), and a very narrow spot at one end, where the whole thing pivots, that feels impossible to make strong enough in the limited space available. There is also a hole down the middle of it at an angle that I could never get right, and in the end, I just printed it solid, then put the hole in with a drill and smoothed with a Dremel. That means no hex-head countersink, but it's not really necessary. I have been able to install this clip, but I'm not sure how well it will hold up to actual use. My fear is it will break more easily than the original (though probably in a different place). So I am uploading this both in case it might be of use to someone else (though really, what are the odds someone else has the same mount I do?) and in case anyone has ideas for a way to replace that clip that won't suffer these problems. For that reason I also included Google SketchUp 8 files.

I printed at 100% infill because I thought it really needed strength.  I also tried to print on non-humid days because this is already struggling to be strong enough, and it's best not to give it any other reasons to be weaker.  
I probably should have printed it in white, since I always get better adhesion in white than in darker colors.  Stupidly I printed in black to match the original parts.  Wonder if white would work better?  If these break and I decide to try again, I'll give white a go.

title: Piece of Cheese Please
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text: The piece of cheese can be used as a key chain, or just to keep around.  It is designed and modeled in inventor and produced using the makerbot.  I decided to use yellow as my color of choice, in order for the cheese's slice to have the same characteristics as real cheese.  This way the cheese slice will look real! I was inspired by my cousin to make this cheese because it is her favorite food.  Even though it will be a gift, I was contemplating on keeping it for myself. I thought that it was silly to make a plastic cheese, but it turned out to be a big hit.

• Create two lines, forming at one point of any degree using the line tool.
  • Next, make a circle and make sure the diameter is alined with the points vertex.
  • Once the lines are joined, use the trim tool to trim away the rest of circle which is not going to be apart of the cheese slice.
  • Then extrude the cheese outline to whatever depth you feel comfortable with and desire.
  • Next, get creative and extrude whereever you want your cheese holes to be on your cheese slice. (make sure to extrude on all sides of the cheese for the most realistic look)
  • Afterwards, Refocus the view in the left lower corner front view in order to see the cheese slice upright.
  • Send code to the maker bot and also changed the units to inches. (generate g-code)
  • Place the cheese on the plateform.
  • Chose colored plastic
  • Wait til cheese slice has cooled
  • Now you have your Cheese Slice!

3Drive is a direct drive extruder for an E3D hotend (but should be easily adaptable for other hotends that use a slot mount), designed with the following criteria:

  • Compact and robust - you can butt two of these end-to-end, or side-to-side, for dual extrusion

  • Close constraint of the filament - I use PTFE tube as filament guide throughout the body (before and after the Mk 8 drive gear), this means flexible filaments should not be a problem.

  • Easy load - I wanted to be able to load new filament without removing the spring tension. The idler body has a thumb flap which lets you open the gap to insert new filament, although in practice the close constraint means that most filaments can just be pushed through without releasing the idler pressure.

  • Mk 8 drive gear - the best drive gear I have yet found, sharp teeth and small circumference.

  • E3D v6 - The mounting is designed for an E3D v6, however that should be easy to adapt for any other groove mount hotend.
    • I mount the hotend from below (rather than a slot mount) using a screw (with oversized washers) mounting system similar to the Mendel 90, because this lets me insert the hotend with PTFE tube already inserted. There are no mounting attachments or holes on the extruder because this was designed to be mounted via the motor (ie, using the 4 screw holes in the back of a stepper motor). I might consider adding other mounting options if there is demand (and someone gives me clear details of what's required). I've included the Sketchup CAD file if anyone wants to modify this. Print in ABS, I'd suggest a 50% infill (if your slicer lets you vary the infill, then the area where the Bowden coupling screws in needs the most strength).

Assembly notes Study the pictures to see where washers are used, the idler bearing has an M4 washer either side (stops it rubbing on the idler body), and an M3 washer is used either side of the idler body pivot, as a spacer (where the idler pivots on the M3 30mm bolt). Don't force the Bowden coupling, on a well calibrated printer you should be able to screw it in to the recess by hand. If you find it is too tight then consider taping the thread first, otherwise you will risk splitting the plastic part. The plastic Bowden coupling came from E3D, my Mk 8 drive gear came from reprap.me, a full BOM is in the attached files. My springs came from the plunge mechanism on a liquid handwash dispenser (500ml size) from a local supermarket.

title: Durafly Zephyr ground plate with skids

description.text:
The Durafly Zephyr has a notorious reputation for its landings. Due to the low wing design combined with its high landing speeds it has shortened the lifespan of many.
I acquired the model a while ago, but never came round on actually assembling the kit and flying it. After reading its thread on rcgroups http://www.rcgroups.com/forums/showthread.php?t=1639354 it became clear the model could use some mods... I've taped the wings to minimize flutter and designed this skid to help it with landing and strengthen the way the wing is attached to the fuselage.
I've taped some velcro on the bottom of the wing, but I went further than the leading edge and is therefore beginning on the top of the wing. With a dremel I made sure that the velcro on top of the wing is as thin as possible so that it doesn't change the angle. This way the velcro can't be just ripped off.
In the design there's some room to glue the other side of the velcro. Finally I also used some glass fibre tape to attach it to front skid.

title: Hobby King P-38 retractable nose gear

description.text:
This is the retractable nose gear assembly that goes with http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:115372. This is for use with the Hobby King P-38 and their 10-15 electric retracts. I used a 20-30mm section of M4 running thread to form the nose strut pivot. The mount and shim was to give a good solid base and to give it the correct forward cant. The integrated servo arm is sized for m2 or you can use #2 x 256 or 1/16".
The axle hole is size for M3. Print with 30-40% infill.

comments.text: Update: I flew three batteries worth on my P-38 doing touch an goes. Something like 10-15 landings. Some nice and gentle, but more that were a not so gentle (still working on that) and the gear was the least of my worries. Very robust.

title: Dual fan mount for Printrbot Simple Metal

description.text: After publishing my experiment about how fans and fan shrouds affect overhang success and appearance, I became curious about whether using dual fans would improve my results. I couldn't find anyone who had made a frame to hold two print-cooling fans onto a Printrbot Simple Metal, so I designed my own. I have experimentally demonstrated that using two fans instead of one improves the printing success and surface quality of tall and thin features like spikes, horns, screws etc, and reduces warping in general. This frame attaches to the existing 40 mm fan mount holes and provides a second 40 mm mount in front of the hot-end (the bed levelling probe prevents me from putting the fan to the side, which is how other printer manufacturers have arranged them). The two fan mounts are equidistant from the hot-end, so you can use any existing fan shroud and be assured that it is pointing at the right place. The demonstration photos show my printer fitted for a test print, with blower fans via my universal blower fan mount supplying EricY's Improved Fan Shroud for jetting air onto the working face from two directions.

description.header: What fan shrouds should you use?
description.text:
According to my experiment, different kinds of fan shrouds are good at different things:
  • Shrouds that focus air at the nozzle are good for overhangs and thin features.
  • Shrouds that blow air broadly over the printing area are good at reducing warping.
    • It's no surprise that the results suggest that you should use one of each! Here's what I use:
  • For the focused shroud, I use EricY's design. I mounted it on the left side of the printer, but I don't think it matters since the dual-fan mount can accept any shroud interchangeably.
  • For broad airflow, I'm actually using the blower fan by itself without a shroud, which is what the experiment showed worked best.
    • I'm working on some shrouds of my own to apply what I've learned.

Do not hot-swap your cooling fans. There is a chance of damaging your controller board. Always turn off and unplug your printer before messing with its wiring. You will need M3 screws and nuts for fitting this frame and its accessories to your printer. I used a range of screw lengths from 15 mm to 30 mm, depending on the shroud I was testing.

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple Black

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 layer, 0.4 nozzle

Infill:

50%

Notes: The angle of the walls is 61°, which is easily achievable without support.

I think the most interesting aspect of the design was how I came up with the spacing and angles to achieve the design goal of holding a second fan at the same distance and angle as the original fan. The most important thing you can do when designing something to fit an existing object is to make a 3D placeholder of the real thing — once you have the placeholder, you just slap some shapes on it and work it until it makes sense. You can see the placeholder I made for this project on Tinkercad. I first made a placeholder of the printer's gantry by measuring the original fan mount and hot-end and producing a 'sketch' with those dimensions using primitive shapes. Then I grabbed a 360° fan shroud like this one and fitted it to the placeholder as it would appear in real life. I duplicated this whole setup and rotated the copy 90°, and then I moved the copy until the space for the hot-end in the shroud was positioned in the same place as the original. Working in context with a template is the easiest way for me to design anything, so I often make template sketches in this manner.

Feb 7 2016
  • Redesigned the whole thing, this time using 50an6xy06r6n's
    Improved Printrbot Fan Duct     as a guide to help me ensure that the front fan plate is correctly positioned (see 'How I Designed This' above).
  • Replaced the front plate mounting holes with slots. Now you can fine-tune the horizontal alignment of your front shroud.
  • Fan holes should be easier to print now that they are octagons instead of rounded squares.
    • Jan 27 2016
  • Fixed a tiny alignment issue by moving the front plate 3mm towards the front of the printer in the Y axis.
    • Nov 27 2015
  • Initial release.

title: Openbeam double beam mounting plate for printable open rail
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
EDITED: some of the holes were off a little. and the screw holes are really tight as well. This is going to be how the axis on the BotBQ will be working. The rails are from Propsfactory on Thingiverse, but had to be modified to 15mm size for Openbeam, but the vwheels are the same size. I created the mounting plate in TinkerCAD and have published it to Thingiverse as well (links below). The bearings are 624zz size and I use two of them on the bracket. The mounting plate still needs some work, but I will update it on thingiverse as improvements are made. Its best to get the bearings in the vwheels as soon as they are done printing as it is easier to put them in there when they are still a little warm. Video: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oCHQfyNuU5M Openrail and V-Wheel from PropsFactory: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:25081
My modified version for 15mm openbeam: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:105833 This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/fsuo7bBetdQ

VITAMINS NEEDED:
Cylinder screws:
M3x6 - 2
M3x8 - 4
M4x16(or 20) - 4 Washers:
M3 - 12
M4 - 32 Nuts:
M3 - 6
M4 lock-nut - 4 Bearings:
624zz - 4 Printed V-Wheel from Propsfactory:
http://www.thingiverse.com/download:75492 Printed OpenRail for 15mm Openbeam:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:105833 PREP:
I suggest having already printed the V-Wheel from Propsfactory and inserted the bearings into them. If you are going to use this rail system, printed and attached the 15mm Openrail for Openbeam from the links above to your openbeam sections... and of course print this mounting plate as well. Also, once you have the plate printed it is advised to lighty go through with 3mm drill bit through the M3 holes and 4mm drill bit through the M4 holes.. just in case they are a little tight. ASSEMBLY:
The two M3x6 go through the bottom of the plate, make sure to add a washer on each side of the plastic, then lightly attach a M3 nut The 4 M3x8 go through each of the upright holes, make sure to add a washer on each side of the plastic, then lightly attach a M3 nut. The 4 M4 screws go through the four outer holes, add one washer before inserting, and 6 washers after, slide the v-wheel/bearing on and add another washer before finally screwing the M4 lock-nut and securing it tightly. Slide your openbeam lengths gently parallel to the plate while fidgeting with the M3 nuts to make sure they align correctly, tighten all M3 cylinder screws to 'just enough' ;-) and BAM you got it. Now slide it onto your printed openrail and your ready to go!

comments.text: Why did you choose to print a rail instead of riding the carriage directly on the very uniform aluminum extrusions? I would think riding on the extrusions would make the motion much smoother
comments.author: QuentinT

comments.text: For strength basically.  If I had one of the official openbeam v-wheels that may be optimal, but since I am using printed pieces I wanted the strength and security of the fitting of the v-wheel and printed rail.
comments.author: QuentinT

title: Nexus 6 & Anker Qi Wireless Charger Stand

description.text:
This is my first 3D Thingy made with Sketchup - so be kind.
This is a phone stand specifically for a Nexus 6 Phone, with a Bumper Case and the Anker Qi Ultra Slim Wireless Charger. While it may work for other phones, the Qi holder is set to the correction position for the Nexus 6. So it may be off for other wireless charging phones.
The Charger Holder part is a bit delicate and flexy, but the Nexus 6 doesn't actually rest against it much - most of that pressure is lower on the stand. 
The rim of the Charger Holder also blocks that annoying flashing blue & green light while its charging the phone.
I'd love to hear from anyone who makes this and any suggestions for improvement.

Do you have problems with filament ooze on your dual extruder prints? Perhaps this idea might help you. This page describes the adaptation of a Bukobot Duo (Original 2012 Version) by Deezmaker to have two x-carriages which can be driven independently instead of the normal single x-carriage with two extruders. The change allows you to park the inactive extruder and prevent it from oozing onto the print when the other extruder is active. In addition to improving dual-extruder printing, the firmware for this design has also been extended to allow you to print two copies of the same object at once (with the heads printing at an arbitrary position and temperature offset). This doubles your printer's output in this case. (see video below)

• The inactive extruder can be parked when not in use.
  • The inactive extruder can be easily capped when parked to prevent runout/ooze (which makes restarting the print more accurate).
  • Each x-carriage is almost half the weight which allows higher print speeds with less backlash.
  • The x-carriages can duplicate one another allow two copies of an object to be printed at one.
  • support for the specification of a Z height offset between the extruder hot ends (if your extruders are not identical).
    • [One other technique some people have used to overcome this problem is to cool the inactive extruder below the oozing temperature at every tool head change. However this massively increases the print time as the printer must wait for the extruder to reach operating temperature at each extruder change,] Short video of operation: http://youtu.be/BHHAHQsAeuA Demo of Duplication Mode: http://youtu.be/Mdj5iZ5B2Dg Tour of printer: http://youtu.be/jAfktjeuPZ4 Picture of original Bukobot Duo here: http://bukobot.com/_detail/buildrob-wiring.jpg The above awesome dragon print model is by tbuser (here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:29088 ). The Ocotpus print is by moleofproduction I've also added links to other 2 color models I've printed in the comments below.

The original Bukobot Duo was actually made up of two single extruder carriages held together with a linking plate and so this modification is accomplished largely by removing the linkage plate, adding additional linear bearings, stepper motor, stepper driver, idler pulleys, synchronmesh cable, end-stop and modifying the X-ends. Full build instructions can be found here: http://bukobot.com/creating-a-dual-x-carriage-bukobot The Bukobot is a fantastic printer. This is not a design fault with the printer but rather a problem common to all dual extruder printers currently out there. By the way, the latest Bukobot Duo design from Bukobot now uses a combined x-carriage which cannot be split. You would likely need to ask Diego for longer X-axis beams, rods and synchromesh cable to fit two of the current X-carriage designs (but that is one of the design features of the Bukobots, i.e., that they can be easily expanded in any direction just by lengthing some rods, beams & cables). The Marlin firmware changes I made to support the Dual X-carriage mode are now integrated into the Marlin github baseline. See Configuration_adv.h.

title: Longer Gimbal arm to mount camera housing

description.text: I was working on a variation of the Open Brushless Gimbal (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:110731), as reworked by MikeyB for the Crossfire platform (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:140126). I have the cheap Denver action cam, so I had actually printed the casing by toto99303 (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:876614), when I found out that the designs of MikeyB and toto99303 weren't quite compatible: two screw mounts for the servo were opposite each other. As I set out to remix, I got a better idea. I noticed that many of the gimbal designs place the camera (be it GoPro or another) out in the open, with only a little plastic to protect it from a crash or hard landing. I've always liked the 'bulletproof' casing that came with my action cam. So what I did is extend one of the arm designs by MikeyB by 2 cm. The hole in the center (normally for the servo axis) is used for the normal tripod screw (M6, I think). The added advantage is that it's a more universal solution than the different boxes for each particular camera type. The only downside I can see is that the camera is off centre of the drone a little now. The photograph shows the principle: you print two sets of arms and attach the camera housing to one of them. I will assemble the whole thing once my servos (finally) arrive.

author: Hermes_aile

description.text: This model is a novelty oversized bolt, intended to aid newer users with learning some of the common functions of their design tools.

When creating my model, I used the CAD program CATIA.
I hope to outline the basic steps I took to create this piece in the following section in a way that can be helpful to students using any 3D modelling program. Step 1: Shaft Create a simple cylindrical shaft with a conical head. Step 2: Screw Drive Remove material from the wider conical surface of the model in the desired screw drive pattern. (For mine I have chosen a simple Phillips head). Step 3: Chamfer Add a chamfer to the end of the bolt. Step 4: Thread Using a helix pattern, remove material along the shaft of the bolt to produce a thread. For an additional challenge, introduce a taper to the thread as it progresses towards the bolt head.

description.header: Project: Remodel Something You See Everyday
description.text:
Objectives
  • Practice the use of given 3D design tool
  • Learn to break a process down into manageable steps
  • Redesign everyday objects for 3D printing
    • Audience
  • All ages
  • Beginner 3D modellers
    • Preparation
  • Student must have access to a computer with 3D modelling software
  • Students should already know the basic functions of their desired program
    • Step 1: Find something ordinary Find an item that can be seen everyday. Step 2: Make something extraordinary Once a mundane item has been chosen, recreate that item in a way that will make it stand out more than it would in it's original state. Step 3: Review and rework Review models and make improvements if required, aim to make the model as efficiently and effectively printable as possible. Results By the end of this project, students should have:
  • Concept sketches/notes on model redesigns
  • Alternate design iterations after reviews
  • A 3D printed model

description.text: I wasn't really happy with the RaspiCam mounts I've tried, so I designed my own. I wanted it to be raised slightly from the bed, and position the camera away from the bed a few inches. It uses camera mount from here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:948307 and that mount just plugs into the bed-mount arm. You can find the 24" flex cable I'm using for the RaspiCam HERE. Here's an example timelapse from the camera mounted on this arm: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RVdlV_OcO8Y

title: New iPhone or iPad Cable Protector

description.text:
I know there are already many of these out but I found that they either didn't fit or didn't look very good. I designed my own one so it looks good and fits well. 
If you want a snug fit then don't scale the file in your slicer. However, if you want a looser fit then I suggest a scale of 1.1 (110%). I used a 0.2mm layer height and a fill density of 15% but you could easily go to 0% and it would be fine. 
NOTE: I always print this with a brim to make it adhere to the build bed much better. I haven't tried without.

Every piece of this fighter jet model was made from a simple shape in Tinkercad. Tinkercad is free, runs in your browser, and is really easy to learn. You can get started with Tinkercad's Lesson Quests or get more in-depth by using Thingiverse's Jumpstart resources for Tinkercad. To scale each shape to the exact size we wanted, we used the Ruler tool from the Helper menu on the right side of the screen. By dragging the Ruler to any point on the blue Workplane, we could see the dimensions of each shape and even change those dimensions by typing the numbers into the dimension text boxes (instead of trying to drag things into the correct size). Here's what things looked like in Tinkercad when we had the Ruler on the Workplane and were working on the first component of the building: To make the rest of the model i just kept adding more component shapes and then dragging them into place. Here's what it looked like partway through the design process:
and thus my model was created

description.header: project:-make a model of flying object with simple tools
description.text:
Objectives
Design and create 3D printed jet from scratch.
Build complex designs from simple component pieces.
Learn basic 3D design skills and how to use Tinkercad or other modeling software.
Explore geography, history, cities, or buildings (depending on classroom usage).
Audiences
Anyone of any age that is new to 3D modeling can use this modeling project to get started with Tinkercad.
Students in grades K-8 can use this project as a jumping-off point for constructing models of local buildings, cities around the world, historical buildings, or imaginary cities from books they are reading.
Preparation
Students will need access to computers and a reliable internet connection, and be logged into a free Tinkercad account (either with their own accounts, or each logged into the same classroom account).
Tinkercad is easier to use with a mouse than with a tablet or trackpad, so computer mice are recommended.
No previous 3D design experience is required for the students, although familiarity with Tinkercad would be helpful.
The instructor should be comfortable answering modeling questions about Tinkercad and be able to advise students to avoid design features that might cause printing difficulties (overhangs, delicate features, etc).
It is helpful to have students form into working groups of two or three so that they can collaborate on the design process. Having students work in groups is also helpful if you have a limited number of computers and/or limited 3D printer access.
Step 1: Choose a jet to model
Step 2: Research and make a sketch of the jet
Step 3: Plan out the jet as a collection of simple components
and implement it

title: Wire Spool Holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I have several spools of wire that were a bit of a mess.  I was either taping the loose wire end or tucking it into the wire.  
I thought a plastic clip to hold it in place would be a better idea - here it is.
The spools I am using are typically available from Fry's or Micro Center.  They are all about 50mm diameter fully loaded and go to about 30 mm empty. As you use the wire and the diameter decreases you'll need to use the smaller clip.
These spools are available in two sizes (height).  The tall spools are about 30mm high, the short spools are 15 mm high.  . 
Here are 4 clips. 2 tall spools  and 2 short spools (full and empty)

Spinning tops are a very interesting toy, with a small twist they can run for quite a while. What makes them more interesting is that with small tweaks and adjustments to them, you can improve the duration and the beauty of each spin; this is why I wanted to submit a spinning top compatible with the customizer. I highly encourage you to tap the "Open in Customizer" button and make your own spinning top creation! See a video here: https://youtu.be/XNZ2iiUVdis. Read more about it on my blog.

Hit the "Open in Customizer" button to customize this top. I wanted to make this design as customizable as I can, you can set:
  • The number of rings
  • Multiple properties on the rings to adjust their appearance.
  • Properties of the shaft and point for spinning balance.
  • Mechanical properties, such as thickness and snugness so it prints best on your printer.
I have also uploaded some pre-rendered if you want to download and print a unit immediately, but I highly recommend opening the customizer and putting in your own values!
I am interested to see what parameters will get this design to spin the longest, if you think you've found a combination that performs well, please do share a video!
If you make this item, please take a moment to take a photograph and upload it to the "makes" section! It makes me very happy to see people print my designs!

Please check out these other customizable items by me: Sharpie Marker Holder
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1147882
Trendy Desktop Bins
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1148371
